column1: Variables in the children's follow-up questionnaire
Green colour of question number in questionnaire: question added or changed, for detailed information, see Reference/comments column.
Blue text in the reference column: the conditions for the question
NOTE: minor changes in language are not found here

column2: Question as answered by child
column4: Reference, comments and possible conditions (in blue) in the question

column2: How tall are you?
column4: Height, weight and waist circumference are without decimals, because they are self-reported and the measurement procedure is inexact

column2: If you are wearing shoes or a cap, please take them off.
Go and stand next to a wall with your back straight.
Keep your legs together and heels against the wall.
Ask someone else to measure your height with the measuring tape from the floor to your head.
Report your height in centimetres, without decimals.
What is your waist circumference?
column4: According to standard procedures, waist circumference is measured midway between the hip bones and the ribs. This is the case in most studies, e.g. the FinnTwin Study (contact person Eila Voipio). Our expert in the collaboration group, Prof. Johan Eriksson, also recommended this site of measurement.

column2: Lift or remove your shirt so that your stomach is bare.
column4: Same instructions as at baseline/pilot: The instruction text is based on Duodecim/Terveyskirjasto (Finnish Health library) with small modifications: http://www.terveyskirjasto.fi/terveyskirjasto/tk.koti?p_artikkeli=dlk00890

column2: Stand up straight, putting your weight equally on both your feet.
Do not suck in your stomach.
Now ask someone to measure around your waistline with the measuring tape like this:

Feel both your sides and the top part of your hip bones. There is a soft area above your hip bones, and above that you can feel your bottom ribs. Measure your waist midway between your hip bones and your ribs.
Hold the measuring tape horizontal. In other words, at the same level around your waist. The measuring tape should not be tight, but not too loose either.
Breathe calmly. Take the measurement when breathing out.
Report your waist circumference in centimetres, without decimals.
How much do you weigh?
Weigh yourself wearing underwear and a light shirt. If you do not have scales at home, you can weigh yourself in the school nurse’s office or at a friend’s home.
Report your weight in kilograms, without grams.
When did you weigh yourself?
column4: is included because we cannot be sure that the participant really weighs herself

column3: I weighed myself within the last month

column2: Which one of the following options best describe your family’s eating at home on school days?
column4: “Hälsoverkstaden” (version 2008), a Finnish school study, based on WHO HBSC (Health Behaviour in School-aged Children) study and THL “Kouluterveyskysely”, the Finnish School Health Promotion study

column3: Not an actual meal but everyone helps themselves to something to eat
column4: Same question as at baseline

column3: A meal is prepared, but the whole family does not normally eat together
A meal is prepared, and the whole family normally eats together

column2: Thinking about the past month, how often did you eat and drink the following food and drinks?
column4: Short food frequency questionnaire.

column2: Dark bread or dark rye bread
column4: Own question, ideas from WHO HBSC (Health Behaviour in School-aged Children) study, “Hälsoverkstaden”, a Finnish school study, THL “Kouluterveyskysely”, the Finnish School Health Promotion study, and THL “Yläkoulututkimus”, a Finnish school study

column2: Biscuits/cookies
Sweet pastry (e.g. bun, doughnut, Danish pastry)
column4: Same food items as at baseline (full recruitment) plus energy drinks (were included in pilot 1), since their consumption might be high among teenagers.

column2: Pizza
Hamburger or hot dog
Milk or soured milk
Ice cream
Cooked vegetables
Fresh or grated vegetables, salad
Fruit or berries
Juice
Sugary juice drink
Chocolate & sweets
Salty snacks (e.g. chips, popcorn, salted peanuts)
Sugary soft drink
Energy drink
Water
How do you feel
column4: We use the same measure in follow-up as used at baseline, Rosenberg Self Esteem Scale, as it is suitable for teenagers, and comparison is easier to do.

column2: I feel that I am a person of worth, at least on an equal plane with others.
column4: Rosenberg M. Society and the Adolescent Self-Image. Princeton: NJ: Princeton University Press; 1965.

column2: I feel that I have a number of good qualities.
column4: Rosenberg M. Society and the Adolescent Self-Image. Revised edition. Middletown, CT: Wesleyan University Press; 1989

column2: All in all, I am inclined to feel that I am a failure.
I am able to do things as well as most other people.
column4: Note! The order of the answer alternatives is the opposite as in the original Rosenberg scale. Please, take that into consideration when calculating the  total scores.

column2: I feel I do not have much to be proud of.
I take a positive attitude toward myself.
On the whole, I am satisfied with myself.
I wish I could have more respect for myself.
I certainly feel useless at times.
At times I think I am no good at all.
How often do you normally exercise or do sports during your free time?
column4: CONDITION: if answered "1-3 times a month" or more, then continue to the following three Physical Activity questions.

column2: Include all the exercise you do in a club or team and any exercise by yourself, with family or friends.
column4: Almost the same question as at baseline, from “Koulut liikkeelle”, a Finnish school study, with small modifications in the definition and answer alternatives.

However, we deleted the text “Do not count any exercise at school or on the way to school”, since we do not have separate questions about physical activity to and from school in the follow-up questionnaire,
and we want to include all free time physical activity in one question.

column3: Seven times a week or more often

column2: How many hours a week do you normally exercise or do sports during your free time?
column3: An hour a week or less
column4: Almost the same question as at baseline, from “Koulut liikkeelle”, a Finnish school study, with small modifications in the definition and answer alternatives.

column2: Include all the exercise you do in a club or team and any exercise by yourself, with family or friends.
column4: We deleted the text “Do not count any exercise at school or on the way to school”, see above.

column3: Ten hours a week or more

column2: On average, how long do you exercise or do sports each time during your free time?
column4: A new question for the follow-up, it is needed in order to count MET (The Metabolic Equivalent of Task).
From the STRIP study, see references: Katja Pahkala. PHYSICAL ACTIVITY IN ADOLESCENCE- with special reference to cardiovascular health, Dissertation, UNIVERSITY OF TURKU, Turku 2009

Raitakari OT et al. Patterns of intense physical activity among 15- to 30 year old Finns. The cardiovascular risk in young Finns study. Scandinavian journal of medicine & science in sports, 1996; 6 (1) 36-39  (pdf nout found in PubMed)

column2: How out of breath do you normally get when you exercise or do sports during your free time?
column3: I do not get out of breath
column4: Intensity of physical activity in the free time.

column3: I get a little bit out of breath
column4: Same question as at baseline. Own question, same structure as in the other intensity questions developed by Dr Minna Aittasalo, researcher at the UKK Institute

column3: I get out of breath a lot
